title: autumnleaf
author: autumnleaf
created_time: January 13, 2023, 01:50:33 AMLast edit: January 14, 2023, 06:21:14 AM by autumnleaf
content: Alejandra Guajardo, who represented El Salvador at Miss Universe 71, wore a costume with a Bitcoin theme. El Salvador is known as the first nation to legalize Bitcoin as a form of payment. Did Miss El Salvador cause the Bitcoin price to spike last night?They just demonstrate to the rest of the world that they are prepared to move beyond simply embracing the cryptocurrency area by changing the way we perceive a cashless society. Adoption is a real phenomenon that won't end there.Source

comments.author: hd49728
comments.body: It is not a Bitcoin adoption and Bitcoin did not pump because of this show. After months of accumulation and with a trend of bullish from stocks, gold in early 2023, Bitcoin joined the trend with its pump recent hours.Adding a Bitcoin icon to her costume is not a Bitcoin adoption. It is a marketing noise, not adoption.Adoption is when there is an agreement between buyer and seller to use Bitcoin as an exchange mean for their trade. The girl did not make any trade with her costume in the show.She could do it by her idea but she could do it with a request from her President Nayib Bukele who strongly loves and supports Bitcoin. He put his nation to a bet with Bitcoin investment, Bitcoin bond (Volcano bond) and I am not surprised if the Venezuela Miss got a request from him.

comments.author: Free Market Capitalist
comments.body: Quote from: hd49728 on January 13, 2023, 02:58:22 AMIt is not a Bitcoin adoption and Bitcoin did not pump because of this show.I agree. It is difficult to know what causes a price spike because there are so many players interacting in the market. I think a price recovery is within the normal range for this 2023 once most of the leverage garbage is gone and we are getting closer to halving, although there is still more to come.The Miss promoting Bitcoin is fine with me, as is anything that helps popularize it, but I think it is extremely unlikely to have anything to do with the price rise.

comments.author: pooya87
comments.body: I doubt that fat guys in their underpants watching Miss Whatever have enough money or even care enough to buy bitcoin, enough to cause a price rise Besides, you are forgetting that it was not "$1000 in last 12 hours", it has been $2600 or 15% rise in the past 10 days. In other words this is an upward trend that has nothing to do with such small news like this but rather a market reversal that may or may not be temporary (depends on whether it breaks $20k or not).

comments.author: Kakmakr
comments.body: Well, as we know.... Bitcoin's price are not just determined by 1 event... but a combination of events in a global context. Yes, a lot of the people watching from El Salvador must have seen that and it might have sparked some marketing affect, but it is insignificant in a global context. I think we are in a slow recovery phase, after all the spending happening over the Holiday season ....and people are returning from their holiday and trading again as usual. (They made profits during the year..... rewarded themselves with a good holiday.. and now they are back at it again.... working to save up for the next holiday)

comments.author: mk4
comments.body: Doubt it. Bitcoin has pretty much been a household name for a while now. A lady wearing a bitcoin-themed dress wouldn't suddenly make people say "omg bitcoin I'm buying now!".

comments.author: davis196
comments.body: I guess that Bitcoin adoption is the only thing El Salvador is famous for. That's why Miss El Salvador is holding a Bitcoin sign.However, this has nothing to do with the BTC price. Maybe this FUD will cause another short term BTC price drop.Will Nexo become the new FTX? We will have to wait and see.

comments.author: Artemis3
comments.body: Actually its a message. She is carrying the now defunct fiat on her back, representing the past, and even older than that cacao/cocoa which was a unit of monetary value at points in history. She carries Bitcoin with her hand, perhaps signaling the country's adoption and spreading the message.So its like someone sponsoring a sports team and stamping a Bitcoin logo in their shirts. It may not be "adoption" but it is promotion and public awareness. Maybe it was Bukele's idea? Who knows, but it is great in my opinion. There are people watching who have not even asked what this Bitcoin is let alone learn that a country adopted it as legal tender (which was said by the announcer).hd49728 Venezuela has no relation, it has the worst fiat of the world, and also the first and failed cbdc (Which was/is a State scam token), their leaderships cannot be worse compared. One puts an end to criminals while the other protects them. And there was some major scandal about Miss Venezuela that dissolved the organization locally or changed hands sometime ago so who knows how that ended (the old fashioned sex for favors).

comments.author: kryptqnick
comments.body: Oh wow, I would've missed this news without this thread, thanks! I don't follow pageants of any levels, but Miss Universe allegedly has 500 million viewers (according to Wikipedia), which is huge if even a part of this audience saw El Salvador's candidate with a giant Bitcoin. I don't know if that's the reason behind the jump, but it could be. In any case, it's a huge promo of Bitcoin for a potentially very fresh audience. I mean, it's not some tech event where most have already heard of Bitcoin before, and I don't think there's a big cross-section between the crypto community and beauty pageant audience, which opens a possibility of wider adoption.
